ranked_diseases.explanation: Classic presentation with infantile spasms, hypsarrhythmia on EEG, and developmental regression/delay. This is the archetypal epileptic encephalopathy presenting in infancy.
Common cause of infantile spasms with hypsarrhythmia. TSC1 mutations frequently present with epilepsy, developmental delay, and can progress to focal seizures.
TSC2 mutations also cause infantile spasms with similar phenotype to TSC1, often with more severe neurological manifestations including absent speech and inability to walk.
X-linked disorder presenting with early-onset seizures including infantile spasms, severe developmental delay, absent speech, and inability to walk. More common in females.
ARX mutations cause X-linked West syndrome with infantile spasms, hypsarrhythmia, and severe intellectual disability. Can affect both males and females.
Early infantile epileptic encephalopathy that can present with infantile spasms, hypsarrhythmia, and severe developmental impairment with absent speech.
Can cause developmental and epileptic encephalopathy with infantile spasms, focal seizures, and severe developmental delay with loss of milestones.
Brain malformation causing infantile spasms, hypsarrhythmia, severe developmental delay, and inability to achieve motor milestones. LIS1 mutations are a common cause.
